syllabus:
\*\*\* UPDATED FOR FALL 2019 \*\*\*

**ENC1011: Major 20th century American Writers /** 二十世紀美國重要作家

高瑪麗/Professor M. Goodwin [profgood@hotmail.com](mailto:profgood@hotmail.com)

Monday 220-520

This course covers a wide range of American fiction from the twentieth century, tracing the formal and thematic developments of the novel in this period and focusing on the relationship between writers and readers, the conditions of publishing, innovations in the novel\`s form, fiction\`s engagement with history, and the changing place of literature in American culture. The reading list includes works by Edith Wharton, John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway, Thomas Pynchon, Toni Morrison and Amy Tan, well as theoretical and critical readings chosen by the instructor.

**Required Texts** (available at Bookman Books and elsewhere, including online)

Cather, Willa _My Antonia_

Faulkner, William _As I Lay Dying_

Kingston, Maxine Hong _The Woman Warrior_

Lee, Harper _To Kill a Mockingbird_

Morrison, Toni _The Bluest Eye_

Vonnegut, Kurt _Slaughterhouse Five_

Critical Readings (through Moodle)

**Evaluation**:

Attendance and Participation: 20%;

Short Writing Responses (2@10% each): 20%

Annotated Bibliography and Presentation: 30%

Final Paper: 30%

  
**Coursework** 

Required work for the course includes careful reading of all assigned material and active participation in class discussions.  Please come to class prepared with questions and comments about the assigned reading for each day--the success of our seminar-style course depends on everyone’s involvement.

**Papers, Presentations**

1.  **Short Writing Responses (2 assignments for short responses on novels, 1-2 pp each)**
2.  **An annotated bibliography that summarizes at least 10 outside sources and two or three major strands of criticism concerning a novel of your choice from the syllabus.  You will present your research findings to the class on the day we discuss the book.**
3.  **Final research paper** that will develop an original argument about some topic in the book, with your reading set in a relevant critical context. 

**Plagiarism**

_Plagiarism, even a first offense, will earn you a failing grade in the course. Plagiarism is defined as “presenting, as one’s own, the work or the opinion of someone else.” Plagiarism is “copying material of some sort, either word for word or sense for sense”; ideas, conclusions, and ways of organizing material can also be plagiarized. Students are guilty of plagiarism when the words, sentences, ideas, conclusions, examples, and/or organization of an assignment are borrowed from a source (a book, an article, online sources, another student’s paper, etc.) without correctly acknowledging the source. If you have any question at all about how to cite sources, check first with the instructor or another faculty member or the MLA Handbook. UPDATE: New department policy is to require major papers to be uploaded into Turn It In, to check for plagiarism._
